Rather these challenges are associated with a concern about the oversimplification by the IPCC of a complex issue in the interests of policy making.
How to reason about uncertainties in the complex climate system and its computer simulations is neither simple nor obvious.

Scientific debates involve controversies over the value and importance of particular classes of evidence as well as disagreement about the appropriate logical framework for linking and assessing the evidence.

The IPCC faces a daunting challenge with regards to characterizing and reasoning about uncertainty, assessing the quality of evidence, linking the evidence into arguments, identifying areas of ignorance and assessing confidence levels.
An overarching concern is how the issue of climate change is framed scientifically and how judgments about confidence in complex scientific arguments are made in view of the cascade of uncertainties.
Given the complexity of the climate problem, ‘expert judgments’ about uncertainty and confidence levels are made by the IPCC on issues that are dominated by unquantifiable uncertainties.
It is difficult to avoid concluding that the IPCC consensus is manufactured and that the existence of this consensus does not lend intellectual substance to their conclusions.

warrant.text: If uncertainties are complex and debates disagree over evidence and logic, then reasoning about the issue is complex and contested.
If a complex, contested issue is oversimplified for policy, the resulting consensus is constructed rather than organically emergent.
If conclusions rest on expert judgments under unquantifiable uncertainties amid acknowledged difficulty, the consensus reflects judgment calls rather than settled knowledge.
An explicit statement that it is difficult to avoid concluding the consensus is manufactured supports that conclusion.
If reasoning is complex and the institution faces a daunting uncertainty task, mere consensus does not add intellectual substance to conclusions.
If challenges are not mere Galileo-style crankery, then the existence of consensus alone does not confer intellectual weight on the conclusions.
Where judgments are dominated by unquantifiable uncertainties, consensus signals agreement not additional evidential substance.

conclusions.canonical: The IPCC consensus is manufactured
The existence of the IPCC consensus does not lend intellectual substance to the IPCC’s conclusions

claims_extra.canonical: Reasoning about climate uncertainty and evidential linking is complex and contested

claims.quote: Making the video was like a deep meditation on the subject of plastic pollution, and we learned some things ourselves as well.
We were already shopping consciously, bringing our own bags, carrying our own water bottles, but we now carry our own utensils in our bags everywhere.
We also became much more aware of how waste and plastics are disposed of and how little we actually recycle.
With this newly learned knowledge we now try to bring awareness to people around us and encourage them to become involved too, in solving this massive problem.
It’s the governments and big corporations that have made it hard for us to live without single-use plastics, such as food packaging, but we are all responsible.
I think it’s more important to try to avoid using single-use plastics than assume that they’ll get recycled once thrown away.
We’ve passed the point of being able to do much about most of the plastic already present in the ocean.
The best thing that people can do is just to try to not make the problem worse.

warrant.text: If most ocean plastic cannot be remediated and avoidance reduces new inputs, then avoiding single-use plastics is the effective lever now.
If the effective lever is to avoid new single-use plastics and the best action is to not make the problem worse, then people should avoid single-use plastics to prevent worsening.
If systemic actors make avoidance hard but responsibility is still shared, then responsibility for mitigation is shared despite barriers.

conclusions.canonical: People should avoid using single-use plastics to avoid making ocean plastic pollution worse
Responsibility for addressing plastic pollution is shared despite systemic barriers

claims_extra.canonical: Avoiding new single-use plastics is the primary effective lever individuals have now

claims.quote: Which brings us to Michael Mann, the fake Nobel laureate currently suing NATIONAL REVIEW for mocking his global-warming “hockey stick. ”

Of the recent congressional hearings, Dr. Mann tweeted that it was “#Science” — i. the guy who agrees with him — vs. “#AntiScience” — i. Judith Curry, chair of the School of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences at the Georgia Institute of Technology.
That’s to say, she is by profession a scientist, but because she has the impertinence to dissent from Dr. Mann’s view she is “#AntiScience. ”
He can’t refute Dr. Curry, he can only label her.
He explains his aversion to appearing with anyone other than fawning groupies thus: “Getting on a debate stage signals that, while you might disagree, you respect the position of your opponent. ”
That’s why he’s suing me over a pun (“tree-ring circus”), why he threatened legal action in Minnesota over a song parody, and why he’s in court in Vancouver objecting to a bit of wordplay.
Steyn’s relentless hammering of Mann seems to be doing far more damage to Mann’s reputation that the alleged legal defamation.

warrant.text: Labeling a dissenting scientist as #AntiScience rather than addressing arguments indicates avoidance of debate.
Refusing to share a stage on the grounds that it signals respect suggests a preference to avoid genuine debate.
Using legal actions over speech acts as a substitute for argument indicates avoidance of debate.
If someone avoids debate and relies on labeling or legal threats, they are not engaging in genuine debate.
If one line of criticism causes greater reputational harm than alleged defamation, then that criticism is the more significant reputational driver.

conclusions.canonical: Michael Mann avoids genuine debate and resorts to labeling or legal threats
Steyn’s criticism is causing more damage to Mann’s reputation than the alleged legal defamation

claims_extra.canonical: Replacing engagement with labeling and legal threats indicates avoidance of genuine debate

claims.quote: These bills arrive at a time when public trust in Australian democracy is in precipitous decline.

Rather than tackling issues that actually concern the Australian public–like excessive corporate influence over our political system–the Government has tabled draconian laws that it hopes will silence its critics.
The importance of NGOs, and their ability to advocate, to the proper functioning of democracy cannot be overstated.
Advocacy ensures that a diverse range of views and voices is represented in policy debate.

While Greenpeace Australia Pacific supporters can be assured that we always speak up for what is right, regardless of the consequences, we are concerned that some charities, particularly smaller ones, may be deterred by these bills from doing so.
Hard right MPs, backed by faceless mining companies, are doing this because they’re afraid of you.

They’re afraid of you because you got every major Australian bank to rule out funding new coal mines , you got BP and Chevron to drop their plans to drill for oil in the Great Australian Bight , and you kicked supertrawlers out of Australian waters .

warrant.text: If NGO advocacy is crucial to proper democratic functioning and ensures diverse voices in debate, then reducing advocacy undermines democratic deliberation.
If bills deter charities from advocacy and advocacy is essential to democratic deliberation, then the bills harm democratic debate.
Laws intended to silence critics suppress advocacy and thereby weaken democratic debate.
Because the text explicitly states the reasons (‘because’)—successful public actions—these serve as evidence for the claim that MPs are afraid.
If actors are afraid of effective public advocacy and they advance laws intended to silence critics, then they are acting to suppress effective public advocacy.

conclusions.canonical: These bills undermine democratic debate by suppressing or deterring advocacy
Hard right MPs backed by mining companies are acting to suppress effective public advocacy

claims_extra.canonical: Silencing or deterring NGO advocacy undermines democratic deliberation

claims.quote: Ms Stephan calls Schellnhuber’s type of climate activism an attempt at creating an “above the law state of emergency”
a new climate religion operated by “high priests”
The new religion promises the Last Judgement already today – that is we endeavour one last huge and dramatic effort to save humanity from a well-deserved downfall.
As is the case with other religions, the best is repentance, humility and self-restriction – preferably through emission payments without end.
Stephan writes that the new climate religion fills a void left behind by other religions, and tells us to feel guilty about prosperity.

Eventually, we fear, we’ll have to pay the price for our prosperity – be it to God or Nature, – with Biblical plagues such as storms, huge tidal waves, floods, fire-spewing volcanoes, in short: death and demons”.
The new priests who proclaim these scenarios have attracted billions of followers with their announcements of world downfall.
And, like all other prophets, they do not tolerate any doubts about their predictions.
Those who dare express doubt are nothing more than egotistical wretches, appeasers and trivializers, block-headed deniers or worse, or to the least paid agents of evil.
it’s only logical that the obstacles that prevent necessary action, like democracy, be removed and replaced globally by an “authoritarian regime of experts”.
The “projected global downfall is the state-of-emergency that justifies every measure and it distracts us from every other unfinished business.

claims.canonical: The movement is quasi-religious and manipulative
Emergency framing licenses above-law, anti-democratic measures
The movement is illegitimate as a guide for policy
The movement is authoritarian and threatens democracy

warrant.text: If a movement exhibits religious features (priests, apocalyptic judgement, repentance, guilt), it is quasi-religious/manipulative.
Quasi-religious/manipulative movements are not legitimate guides for public policy.
Movements that do not tolerate doubt display authoritarian tendencies.
Stigmatizing dissenters indicates intolerance of pluralism consistent with authoritarianism.
Creating an ‘above the law state of emergency’ implies suspending normal legal constraints.
If a projected downfall is used as a state of emergency that ‘justifies every measure’, extraordinary above-law powers are being claimed.
If emergency framing licenses above-law measures, the resulting governance is authoritarian and threatens democracy.
If it is ‘only logical’ to remove democratic obstacles and replace them with an authoritarian regime of experts, then the movement promotes authoritarian outcomes.
Mass followings driven by doomsday announcements suggest persuasive appeal rather than reliable policy guidance.

conclusions.canonical: The movement is illegitimate as a guide for policy
The movement is authoritarian and threatens democracy

The IPCC faces a daunting challenge with regards to characterizing and reasoning about uncertainty, assessing the quality of evidence, linking the evidence into arguments, identifying areas of ignorance and assessing confidence levels.
An overarching concern is how the issue of climate change is framed scientifically and how judgments about confidence in complex scientific arguments are made in view of the cascade of uncertainties.

claims_extra.canonical: Reasoning about climate uncertainty and evidential linking is complex and contested

If a complex, contested issue is oversimplified for policy, the resulting consensus is constructed rather than organically emergent.
If conclusions rest on expert judgments under unquantifiable uncertainties amid acknowledged difficulty, the consensus reflects judgment calls rather than settled knowledge.

If reasoning is complex and the institution faces a daunting uncertainty task, mere consensus does not add intellectual substance to conclusions.
If challenges are not mere Galileo-style crankery, then the existence of consensus alone does not confer intellectual weight on the conclusions.
